title-group.article-title: Cloning and expression of alkane hydroxylase-1 from Alcanivorax borkumensis in Escherichia coli

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Genetics, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran
2National Institute for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (NIGEB), Tehran, Iran
3Faculty of Biological Sciences, Shahid Beheshti University, Tehran, Iran
4Department of Genetics, Tehran Medical Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Bijan Bambai, Faculty of Biological Sciences, Shahid Beheshti University, Tehran, 1983963113, Iran. Email: B_Bambai@sbu.ac.ir

abstract.p: Enzymes with hydroxylating activity on alkanes have potential application as biotransformation catalysts in chemical and pharmaceutical industry. Genome of Alcanivorax borkumensis, a marine bacterium with hydrocarbon dissimilation activity, contains at least two P450 monooxygenases and two nonheme monooxygenases, AlkB1 and AlkB2, respectively. Presumably, all these enzymes possess alkane hydroxylating activity. Both AlkB1 and AlkB2 are membrane proteins. Two accessory proteins, rubredoxin and rubredoxin reductase, supply the reducing equivalent from nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate reduced (NADPH to hydroxylases. Rubredoxin reductase catalyses the reduction of rubredoxin by oxidation of NADPH, and rubredoxin transfers the electrons to the alkane hydroxylase to complete the hydroxylation reaction. Here, we sought to investigate the expression of alkB1 gene in Escherichia coli. Therefore, we amplified alkB1 gene from A. borkumensis genome by polymerase chain reaction and cloned it in the expression vector pET26 upstream of His-tag sequence. Predisposed BL21 (DE3) cells were transformed by the recombinant vector. At last, expression of recombinant enzyme was confirmed by sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blotting. Regarding the potential ability of this enzyme in hydroxylation of long-chained alkanes, the application of it would be studied in petroleum downstream industries.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Various types of marine microorganisms are isolated with the ability to metabolize hydrocarbons including crude oil. Among these organisms, Alcanivarax barkumensis SK2 is a gram-negative proteobacter first reported from Borkum island in North Sea in 1998 (Kasai et al., 2001; van Beilen et al., 2005). Due to the unique nutritional dependence of this bacterium on hydrocarbon, populations of A. borkumensis were found as the main constituent of microbial population in oil-polluted marine environments all around the world (Harayama et al., 2004; Kasai et al., 2002).

The C–H bond is chemically stable and requires high activation energy (435 KJ Mol–1) in catalytic reactions. Hydroxylating the terminal methyl group of alkanes is the first and key enzymatic reaction in the pathways for extracting energy from this class of molecules, leading to the generation of primary alcohols. The alkane hydroxylating system is composed of three components, hydroxylase, rubredoxin and rubredoxin reductase. This enzyme complex is able to oxidize long- and medium-chain alkanes, using reductive equivalents from nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide reduced (NADH) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate reduced (NADPH) (Ayala and Torres, 2004; Udit et al., 2004).

There are two annotated alkane hydroxylase genes, namely alkB1 and alkB2, in published genome of A. borkumensis (Schneiker et al., 2006). Alkane hydroxylase-1 (ALKB1) efficiently oxidizes medium-chain (C5–C12) alkanes, while alkane hydroxylase-2 (ALKB2) oxidizes medium-chain (C8–C16) alkanes (Smits et al., 2003). Both ALKB1 and ALKB2 are membrane diiron monooxygenases. These enzymes have potentially numerous applications in the transformation of hydrocarbons.

Regarding the function of ALKB1 enzyme in alkane metabolism and in order to apply this enzyme potentially to produce high value-added fine chemicals from relatively cheap hydrocarbon compounds, the ability of recombinant Escherichia coli cells in expression of ALKB1 was examined. The absence of alcohol oxidation enzymes in E. coli prevents the conversion of newly synthesized alcohol into corresponding aldehyde and fatty acid. Therefore, production of a recombinant alkB1 is superior to the employment of native strain with downstream enzymes.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: A. borkumensis SK2 (DMS 11573T) was obtained from Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und zellkulturen (DSMZ, http://www.dsmz.de). In this research, E. coli was exercised as a host for cloning and expression as well.

sec.title: Medium and growth conditions
sec.p: A. borkumensis SK2 was grown at room temperature in artificial seawater medium (pH 7–7.5) with the following compositions: NaCl (23 g/l), MgSO4.7H2O (5.8 g/l), MgCl2.2H2O (6.16 g/l), CaCl2.H2O (1.47 g/l), Na2HPO4.7H2O (0.89 g/l), NaNO3 (5 g/l) and FeSO4.7H2O (0.03 g/l) for 24 h. This basal medium was supplemented with remnant oil (0.25%; 15 °American Petroleum Institute [API]) as the sole source of carbon.
Primers based on ALKB1 are coded by ABO_2707 (Hara et al., 2004).

sec.title: A. borkumensis SK 2 genomic DNA extraction
sec.p: Genomic DNA extraction kit (Metabion, Germany) was applied to extract genomic DNA of A. borkumensis. The extraction method was according to recommendation provided by the supplier. Briefly, cells from 1.5 ml overnight culture were pelleted and were lysed and the genome was dissolved in 30 µl double-distilled water and stored at –20°C for further applications.

sec.title: AlkB-1 amplification
sec.p: A total of 2 ng of purified genomic DNA was used as template in a PCR containing 2.5 µL 10× buffer, 200 µM deoxynucleotide triphosphate (dNTP) and 0.5 U pfu DNA polymerase (Fermentase GmbH, Germany) with 20 pmol of each forward primer (ALKB1-F1; 5′CATATGTCAGAGAACATTTTAACC3′) and reverse primer (ALKB1-R2; 5′TTAGTGATGGTGATGGTGGTGTTTGGCAACGGTTG3′) in a final volume of 25 µL. The primers were designed based on the deposited alkB-1 sequence (ABO_2707), with forward primer having a NdeI restriction site (underlined) and the reverse primer having the 6xHis-tag sequence. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) steps included 1 min at 94°C, 30 cycles of 30 sec at 94°C, 40 sec at 50°C and 2 min at 68°C, and one cycle of 10 min at 72°C.

sec.title: Cloning of the PCR product
sec.p: The PCR product (˜1300 bp) was purified by High Pure PCR Purification kit (Roche, Germany) and then cloned into EcoRV linearized pGEM_5ZF vector (Promega, Fitchburg, Wisconsin) by T4 DNA ligase for 16 min at 22°C. Competent DH5α cells were transformed with ligation mixture and some white colonies were screened for the presence of AlkB1 DNA. One of the recombinant plasmids, named pGEM_ALKB1, was NdeI/SalI double-digested and the alkB1 fragment was ligated into NdeI/SalI double-digested pET-26b(+) plasmid. Again, competent DH5α cells were transformed with the second ligation mixture and some colonies from kanamycin containing plate were screened for the presence of AlkB1 DNA. Afterward, the above said bacteria were cultured on Luria–Bertani (LB) media containing kanamycin. One of the positive plasmids was called pET26_ALKB1 and was used for further sequencing and expression experiments.

sec.title: Expression of recombinant ALKB1 in E. coli (BL21) cells
sec.p: After confirming recombinant pET26_ALKB1 plasmid sequence, predisposed cells of E. coli (BL21) were transformed by the plasmid. Then, a colony of newly cultured E. coli (BL21) cells, containing pET26_ALKB1 vector, was cultured in a liquid LB culturing condition, containing kanamycin, at 37°C for 16 min at 200 rpm. Then, the cells were grown at 37°C at 200 rpm in the medium containing 19.95 g/l KH2PO4, 6 g/l (NH4)2HPO4, 1.2 g/l MgSO4. 7H2O, 10 g/l glucose, 10 g/l peptone and 0.5 ml of stock solution of trace elements supplemented with kanamycin at final concentration of 50 μg/ml until the cell density reached OD600nm (Optical Density at 600 nm) of 0.6. Afterward, the expression of protein was inducted by adding isopropyl thiogalactoside (IPTG) at final concentration of 0.5 mM at 30°C for time intervals indicated in Figure 3. In order to study the expression of recombinant protein, it was sampled from cultured condition at different times before and after the induction. The samples were kept at –20°C until preparing for the experiment.

sec.title: Preparing the sample for sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) vertical electrophoresis
sec.p: The bacterial cells produced from 1 ml cellular culturing have been settled by centrifuging at 8000 rpm, at room temperature for 5 min. The sediment of the bacterial cells was dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS 1×). After adding a certain amount of sample solvent 6× (pH = 6.8), it is boiled for 3 min. A certain amount of sample solvent 6× (pH = 6.8) was added to the supernatant and was boiled for 3 min. The prepared samples were studied by SDS-PAGE.

sec.title: Solutions and buffers used for Western blotting
sec.p: The solutions used for Western blotting are transfer buffer (pH = 8.3), Tris buffered saline (TBS), Tween/Trion, TBS buffer (pH = 7.5), TBS-Tween buffer (pH = 7.5), buffer (pH = 7.5) and staining solution. After preparing the samples for SDS-PAGE and electrophoresis, the proteins were transferred onto the nitrocellulose membrane by placing the gel over the membrane. The membrane of nitrocellulose was washed twice (pH = 4.5) for 10 min. Afterward, the membrane was incubated at room temperature in blocking buffer for 1 hr. After this level, the membrane was washed by TBS-Tween/Trion buffer for 10 min. Then, the membrane was incubated in blocking buffer containing diluted (1:200) ‘Anti-His-tag’ antibody conjugated with Horse Radish Peroxidase (HRP) at room temperature, and agitated for 2 hr. Then, the membrane was washed (3x) in TBS-Tween/Triton buffer and TBS buffer (2x). At last, 18 mg substrate (4-chloro-1-naphthol) was dissolved in 6 ml methanol to which 24 ml of TBS buffer was added. This mixture was poured on the nitrocellulose membrane to which 60 ml of H2O2 (30%) was added. The solution was rocked until the color development was stabilized. After termination of the reaction and appearance of bands, the membrane was washed with distilled water.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Electrophoresis of PCR product on 1% agarose gel shows a band at the area of 1200 base pair (bp), which was completely predictable as corresponding to the sequence of ALKB1 gene as deposited in NCBI (Figure 1 , lane 6). Both the PCR product and the cloning vector were digested with the same restriction enzyme (EcoRV) to produce compatible ends for litigation reaction. Following gel purification of both fragments, they were litigated to form the recombinant vector. The recombinant vectors containing the ALKB1 in the correct direction were selected by digestion with BglI. The cloning vector used in this research is pGEM_5ZF. The vector pGEM_5ZF has 3001 bp, and the recombinant vector pGEM_ALKB1 was of the size 4216 bp after the ALKB1 was inserted into it (Figure 1, lane 3). In order to confirm the presence of ALKB1 gene piece in recombinant pGEM_ALKB1, two techniques, colony PCR and enzyme cutting by restriction enzyme BglI, were exercised for 3 hr. In colony PCR reaction, pGEM_ALKB1 was used as a pattern and the primers ALKB1_F1 and ALKB1_R1 were the same as before (Figure 1, lane 7). The BglI has two cutting sites in the gene ALKB1 of which one of them is at nucleotide 665 and the other is at nucleotide 864. Also, it has three cutting sites in nucleotides 39, 1515 and 2834 in the vector pGEM_5ZF. In case of the presence of the considered gene, four pieces would be obtained (Figure 1, lane 4). Both confirming tests show the accuracy of cloning. After cloning the gene ALKB1 into the vector and confirming by studying the expression, the gene ALKB1 was taken out of the recombinant vector pGEM_ALKB1 using the enzymes SalI and NdeI through the expression vector pET-26b(+) to be cloned in lower part of promoter T7. Figure 2 , lane 5, indicates gene ALKB1 after simultaneous cutting with SalI and NdeI. As it is observed, a part of cut recombinant plasmid in lane 6 and a piece of gene related to the gene ALKB1 (1215 bp) have been separated, and the upper band with the size of 3000 bp belongs to plasmid pGEM_5ZF (Figure 2, lane 6).

caption.p: Cloning analysis through colony PCR method and enzyme digestion in plasmid pGEM_5ZF. 1. Molecular weight marker (1 Kb DNA ladder). 2. Plasmid pGEM_5ZF without external piece (negative control). 3. Recombinant plasmid containing piece ALKB1 (4216 base pair [bp]). 4. Recombinant plasmid enzyme cutting pGEM_5ZF by the enzyme BglI. 5. Recombinant plasmid enzyme cutting pGEM_5ZF by enzymes SalI and NdeI. 6. PCR production, gene ALKB1 (1215 bp). 7. Colony polymerase chain reaction ([PCR] 1215 bp).

Cloning analysis through colony polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method and enzyme expression in plasmid pET-26b(+). 1. Molecular marker (1 Kb DNA ladder). 2. Plasmid pET-26b(+) without external piece, 5360 base pair (bp; negative control). 3. Recombinant plasmid containing piece ALKB1 (6575 bp). 4. Recombinant plasmid enzyme cutting pET26_ALKB1 by enzymes SalI and NdeI. 5. PCR production, gene ALKB1 (1215 bp). 6. Colony PCR (1215 bp).

sec.p: The ALKB1 gene was expressed in pET-26b(+). The ligation reaction between the double digested ALKB1/SalI+NdeI and pET-26b/SalI+NdeI double digested, resulted in the recombinant vector pET26_ALKB1 (˜6600 bp). The correct orientation of inserted fragment in pET26 was confirmed by SalI/NdeI double digestion (Figure 2, lane 4) and DNA sequencing of the selected plasmid. Then, the expression of ALKB1 enzyme hosted by E. coli (BL21) was examined using SDS-PAGE technique and Western blot. In this research, in order to express the recombinant enzyme, defined condition was used that contains glucose as an organic carbon resource (Figure 3 ).

caption.p: The results of protein ALKB1 electrophoresis. 1. MI—protein marker 10–200 kDa (#SM0661). 2 and 8. In order: pellete and supernatant of nonrecombinant bacteria. 3 and 9. In order: pellete and supernatant, T0 sample. 4, 5, 6 and 7. Expression of membrane protein ALKB1, after 2, 4, 6 and 16 h of induction by isopropyl thiogalactoside (IPTG). 10, 11, 12 and 13. Sample of supernatant after 2, 4, 6 and 16 h of induction by IPTG.

sec.p: In this research 5% (volume-by-volume [v/v]) of bacteria cultured overnight was used for insemination and an optical density (OD) of 0.6 was selected as the proper cellular density. Usually 16–24 h is required for producing enzyme and the production rate is maximized during this time. According to the reports of this research, temperature of 30°C and 150 rpm are used (van Beilen et al., 2005). Also, the studies show that ALKB1 is a protein containing nonheme diiron, which is connected to the membrane (Smits et al., 2002), and the expression is stimulated in delayed exponential phase. When the rate of growth is decreased (Marín et al., 2003), the expression of recombinant protein is accomplished in the peripelasmic or extracellular space and only minor expression is observed in the cytoplasm of expressed cell. Figure 3 confirms these assumptions based on our SDS-PAGE results.

Also, for studying the presence of (His)6_tag_tail that is placed at the end of the protein ALKB1, Western blot test with Anti-HRP conjugate was done. Hence, the appeared band of 46 kDa is related to the protein ALKB1 (Figure 4 ).

caption.p: Protein ALKB1 Western blot. (A) Expression of protein ALKB1 containing His_tag. Bar 1: expression of histidinated intercellular protein ALKB1, Bar 2: negative control, Bar 3: M1_protein marker 10–200 kDa (#SM0661). (B) Protein ALKB1 Western blot. Bar 1: sample of intercellular protein ALKB1, Bar 2: M2_Protein Marker (#SM0241) prestained protein molecular weight marker.

sec.p: In conclusion, the expression of alkane hydroxylase-1 (ALKB1) in recombinant E. coli system will pave the way for a better understanding of the catalytic mechanism of this interesting non-heme oxygenases. Availability of other hydroxylazing enzymes (Miri et al., 2008) and accessory proteins (rubredoxin and rubredoxin reductase) will lead to development of decontamination systems for a fast and environmentally friendly approach to bioremediation of oil contaminated water and soil (Rojo, 2009). Furthermore, there are other applications including biotransformation of common starting materials into fine chemical production via this enzyme system.
